messageBody:
Homolgize causing to have the same relative position, value, or
structure.

(PAIGE) Although I have not studied the history of English spelling
per se, it appears to me that we got into this mess due

(1) to the wide distribution of English speakers around the world,
(2) the insistence on spelling standardization and
(3) the lack of any mechanism that could enforce updated spelling
changes to keep the written language in sync with the spoken tongue.

(STEVE) Spanish has the same wide distribution around the world and
is standardized.

They do attempt to update spelling to keep spelling in sync with the
way words are pronounced. This effort is difficult because same word
may have several pronunciations in different regions. A writing
system can be 100% phonemic with respect to a single dialect.


(PAIGE) I can't see any way this could be done with English. '

(Steve) You would first have to have one system for English
spelling. At the present time English has at least 4.
QS is based on one system of spelling. It is a pronunciation guide
or dictionary key spelling system.

If there were one system, then English could be updated as easily as
Spanish and German. However, most have learned English as a system
of word-signs or meaning signs (sema-grams). They are therefore very
reluctant to change any spellings since it makes the semagrams harder
to recognize.

(PAIGE) The prediction that one dialect in English may win out over
others due to the impact of the media does not seem particularly
likely to me. I can listen to Peter Jennings for years, but that has
not affected my own idiolect as far as I can tell.

(STEVE) Having a prestige dialect does not mean that everyone speaks
it altho they probably could come very close if they had to.

The Castlian dialect has not won over all Spanish speakers but it
does have the closest fit to the spelling system.

We could use a widely known dialect such as NBC English the prestige
dialect or we could set up an artificial dialect based on a
simplified system of spelling. (See Globish).

We want it to be possible to pronounce words as they are spelled and
be understood. This is quite a different goal that that of the
descriptive linguist.

> -----Original Message-----

(ALCOLYTE)
> One of the reasons QS was made was to get rid of the problems in
> standardized spelling. If QS actually does succeed as the standard
> (good luck!) Merrian-Webster and every other dictionary maker will
> print dictionaries in QS (or have the word in QS and the def. in
> Roman.) People will likely do the same thing with that as they do
with
> the Roman alphabet. Desire for set structure and order is basic part
> of human nature. It is shown in all religion, from the Celtic to
> Christianaty and is obviously manifest in the city based society
> today. Standardized spelling has been instutionalized as one more
> thing to keep in order, and it is very likely that it will be passed
> from parents and teachers to children. '

The simplicity and speed of QS are probably the only benefits it will
hold if it ever becomes widely used. Even if that doesn't happen
(maybey especially) one dialect may eventually become the predominant
one by the wide circulation of media
> from it. If people start speaking the way they read, which is quite
> possible through the whole sub-vocalization process that people do
> when reading, then what they read the most may change their own
> speech, and in turn change their friends' speech, etc. (Was that
> apostraphe right? Stupid bloody possesive plurals...) making, most
> likely, the western US accent go almost worldwide. Of course New
York
> will never change because they still haven't despite the attempts
> we've made to fix th I mean the amount of television with our accent
> that they have been exposed to, but that is, of course, fine (whew,
> that was a close save...) The main British accent may also win out,
> there are quite a few books coming to the US from there. More likely
> is a mixture, especially since the main TV ones are about the same
(if
> that guy that NPR rebrodcasts from the BBC is representative of the
> majority of Britan.)

> So what do you all think about that hypothesis? It would solve the
> copy-cat spelling problem, because we'd all talk the same anyway so
> phonetics would work fine in all cases. (Almost.)
> But that would take years and years (or decades and decades of
> decadence... sorry, I just had to do that for the parrallelism) so
the dictionary spelling will more likely take back over.

> And this has likely been discussed, but what can actually be done to
> prevent the spelling problems? I suppose a lot of that can be how it
> is presented: spelling doesn't matter, it is made to be flexible. I
> think that needs to be emphasized.
